questions.text: A can complete a work in 20 days and B can complete it in 30 days. How many days will they take to complete the work together?
questions.explanation:
Given: A completes work in 20 days, B completes work in 30 days

Step 1: Find one day's work for each
A's one day work = 1/20
B's one day work = 1/30

Step 2: Find combined one day's work
Combined one day's work = 1/20 + 1/30

To add fractions, find LCM of 20 and 30 = 60
= 3/60 + 2/60
= 5/60
= 1/12

Step 3: Find time taken together
If one day's work = 1/12, then time taken = 12 days

Alternatively using formula:
Time = (a × b)/(a + b) = (20 × 30)/(20 + 30) = 600/50 = 12 days

Therefore, A and B together will complete the work in 12 days.

questions.text: A is 50% more efficient than B. If B can complete a work in 30 days, in how many days can A complete the same work?
questions.explanation:
Given: A is 50% more efficient than B, B completes work in 30 days

Step 1: Understand efficiency relationship
If B's efficiency = 100%, then A's efficiency = 100% + 50% = 150%
Ratio of efficiency (A : B) = 150 : 100 = 3 : 2

Step 2: Find time relationship
Efficiency and time are inversely proportional
If efficiency ratio is 3:2, then time ratio is 2:3 (inverse)

Step 3: Find A's time
If B takes 30 days (corresponding to ratio 3)
Then A takes: (2/3) × 30 = 20 days

Alternatively:
B's one day work = 1/30
A is 50% more efficient, so A's one day work = 1.5 × (1/30) = 1.5/30 = 1/20
Therefore, A takes 20 days

Verification:
A's work per day = 1/20
B's work per day = 1/30
Ratio = (1/20) : (1/30) = 3:2 ✓
A is 50% more efficient than B ✓

Therefore, A can complete the work in 20 days.
